speaker: Stumpy

speaker: Jim Wheeler

utterance: to let this yer young man from Roaring Camp-an entire stranger-carry away our money.
speaker: Jim Wheeler

utterance: Tommy, you're a good little man, but you can't gamble worth a cent. Don't try it over again.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: Alone?
speaker: Tom Simson

utterance: Piney can stay with Mrs. Oakhurst, and I can shift for myself.
speaker: Tom Simson

utterance: Is this yer a d-d picnic?
speaker: Uncle Billy

utterance: That is, if you're willing to board us. If you ain't—and perhaps you'd better not -you can wait till Uncle Billy gets back with provisions.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: They'll find out the truth about us all when they find out anything, and there's no good frightening them now.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: We'll have a good camp for a week, and then the snow'll melt, and we'll all go back together.

utterance: I reckon now you're used to fine things at Poker Flat.

utterance: I'm proud to live in the service of the Lord, And I'm bound to die in His army.'

speaker: Tom Simson

utterance: Poker!
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: when a man gets a streak of luck,-nigger-luck,-he don't get tired. The luck gives in first. Luck, is a mighty queer thing. All you know about it for certain is that it's bound to change. And it's finding out when it's going to change that makes you. We've had a streak of bad luck since we left Poker Flat, you come along, and slap you get into it, too. If you can hold your cards right along you're all right. For,
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: I'm proud to live in the service of the Lord And I'm bound to die in His army.'
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: Just you go out there and cuss, and see.
speaker: Mother Shipton

utterance: I'm going, but don't say anything about it. Don't waken the kids. Take the bundle from under my head and open it.
speaker: Mother Shipton

utterance: Give 'em to the child.
speaker: Mother Shipton

utterance: You've starved yourself.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: That's what they call it.
speaker: Mother Shipton

utterance: There's one chance in a hundred to save her yet, but it's there.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: And you?
speaker: Tom Simson

utterance: I'll stay here.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: You are not going, too?
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: As far as the cañon.
speaker: Oakhurst

utterance: Piney, can you pray?
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: No, dear.

utterance: Miggles! O Miggles!
speaker: the driver

utterance: Migg-ells! You Miggles!
speaker: the driver

utterance: Migglesy!
speaker: the expressman

utterance: O Miggy! Mig!
speaker: the expressman

utterance: if we didn't want to sit in the coach all night, we had better rise up and sing out for Miggles.
speaker: the driver

utterance: May-gells!
speaker: a Hiber-

utterance: Miggles
speaker: a magpie

utterance: Extraordinary echo.
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: Extraordinary d-d skunk! Come out of that, Miggles, and show yourself! Be a man, Miggles! Don't hide in the dark; I wouldn't if I were you, Miggles,
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: Miggles! O Miggles!
speaker: a magpie

utterance: Consider the inhospitality of refusing shelter from the inclemency of the weather to helpless females. Really, my dear sir-
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: Do you know this Miggles?
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: No, nor don't want to.
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: But, my dear sir,
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: Lookee here, hadn't you better go back and sit in the coach till yer introduced? I'm going in,
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: Hello, be you Miggles?
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: Miggles! Be you deaf? You ain't dumb anyhow, you know;
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: Well, dern my skin,
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: It is evident that either our distinguished friend here has reached that condition described by Shakespeare as 'the sere and yellow leaf,' or has suffered some premature abatement of his mental and physical faculties. Whether he is really the Miggles-
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: Miggles! O Miggles! Migglesy! Mig!
speaker: a magpie

utterance: Thar ain't nobody but him within ten mile of the shanty, and that 'ar d-d old skeesicks knows it.
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: O, if you please, I'm Miggles!
speaker: Miggles

utterance: You see, boys, I was mor'n two miles away when you passed down the road. I thought you might pull up here, and so I ran the whole way, knowing nobody was home but Jim,-and-and-I'm out of breath-and-that lets me out.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: I'll trouble you for that thar har-pin.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: This afflicted person is-
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: Jim.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: Your father?
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: No.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: Brother?
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: No.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: Husband?
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance: No; it's Jim.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Come, you must be hungry. Who'll bear a hand to help
me get tea?
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
That's Joaquin, would you like
to see him?
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
That's
my watch-dog. O, he
don't bite.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: Does he, old Toppy?
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
I tell you what, boys, you were in big luck that Joaquin wasn't hanging
round when you dropped in to-night.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Where was
he?
speaker: the Judge

utterance:
With me. Lord love you; he trots round with me nights like as
if he was a man.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
You, boys, will have to
camp out here by the fire as well as you can, for thar ain't but the one room.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
If it's all the same to you, boys, as we're rather
crowded, I'll stop here to-night.
speaker: Miggles

utterance: Is there any of you that knows me?
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Think again! I lived at Marysville in '53. Every-
body knew me there, and everybody had the right to
know me. I kept the Polka Saloon until I came to
live with Jim. That's six years ago. Perhaps I've
changed some.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Well, you see I thought some of you must have
known me. There's no great harm done, anyway.
What I was going to say was this: Jim here used to
know me, if you didn't, and spent a heap of money
upon me.
I reckon he spent all he had. And one
day—it's six years ago this winter-Jim came into my
back room, sat down on my sofy, like as you see him
in that chair, and never moved again without help.
He was struck all of a heap, and never seemed to
know what ailed him. The doctors came and said as
how it was caused all along of his way of life,—for
Jim was mighty free and wild like,—and that he would
never get better, and couldn't last long anyway. They
advised me to send him to Frisco to the hospital, for
he was no good to any one and would be a baby all
his life. Perhaps it was something in Jim's eye, per-
haps it was that I never had a baby, but I said 'No.'
I was rich then, for I was popular with everybody,-
gentlemen like yourself, sir, came to see me,—and I
sold out my business and bought this yer place, be-
cause it was sort of out of the way of travel, you see,
and I brought my baby here.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
It was a long time before I could get the hang
of things about yer, for I was used to company and
excitement. I couldn't get any woman to help me,
and a man I dursent trust; but what with the Indians
hereabout, who'd do odd jobs for me, and having
everything sent from the North Fork, Jim and I
managed to worry through. The Doctor would run
up from Sacramento once in a while. He'd ask to
see 'Miggles's baby,' as he called Jim, and when he'd
go away, he'd say, 'Miggles; you're a trump,-God
bless you;' and it didn't seem so lonely after that.
But the last time he was here he said, as he opened
the door to go, 'Do you know, Miggles, your baby
will grow up to be a man yet and an honor to his
mother; but not here, Miggles, not here!' And I
thought he went away sad,-and-and-
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Miggles; you're a trump,-God
bless you;
speaker: the Doctor

utterance:
Do you know, Miggles, your baby
will grow up to be a man yet and an honor to his
mother; but not here, Miggles, not here!
speaker: the Doctor

utterance:
The folks about here are very kind. The men from the fork used to hang around here,
until they found they wasn't wanted, and the women
are kind,—and don't call. I was pretty lonely until
I picked up Joaquin in the woods yonder one day,
when he wasn't so high, and taught him to beg for
his dinner; and then thar's Polly-that's the magpie
-she knows no end of tricks, and makes it quite
sociable of evenings with her talk, and so I don't feel
like, as I was the only living being about the ranch.
And Jim here, why, boys, you would admire to see how much he
knows for a man like him. Sometimes I bring him
flowers, and he looks at 'em just as natural as if he
knew 'em; and times, when we're sitting alone, I read
him those things on the wall. Why, Lord! I've read him that
whole side of the house this winter. There never was
such a man for reading as Jim.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
Why, do you not marry this
man to whom you have devoted your youthful life?
speaker: the Judge

utterance:
Well, you see, it would be play-
ing it rather low down on Jim, to take advantage of
his being so helpless. And then, too, if we were man
and wife, now, we'd both know that I was bound to
do what I do now of my own accord.
speaker: Miggles

utterance:
It's getting late, and
you'd better all turn in. Good-night, boys;
speaker: Miggles

utterance: All aboard
speaker: Yuba Bill

utterance: Are your glasses charged, gentlemen?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Well, then, here's to Miggles, GOD BLESS HER!
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Call yourself Clifford, do you? hell is full of such Cliffords!
speaker: Boston

utterance:
And now, young man, I'll trouble you your knife,
your pistols, and your money. You see your weppings
might get you into trouble at Red Dog, and your
money's a temptation to the evilly disposed. I think
you said your address was San Francisco. I shall
endeavor to call.
speaker: Tennessee

utterance: What have you got there?—I call.
speaker: Tennessee

utterance: Two bowers and an ace.
speaker: the stranger

utterance: That takes me.
speaker: Tennessee

utterance: I don't take any hand in this yer game.
speaker: Tennessee

utterance:
I was passin' by, and I thought I'd just step in and see how things
was gittin' on with Tennessee thar,—my pardner. It's
a hot night. I disremember any sich weather before
on the Bar.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Have you anything to say in behalf of the prisoner?
speaker: the Judge

utterance:
Thet's it. I come yar as Tennessee's pardner,-knowing
him nigh on four year, off and on, wet and dry, in
luck and out o' luck. His ways ain't allers my ways,
but thar ain't any p'ints in that young man, thar ain't
any liveliness as he's been up to, as I don't know.
And you sez to me, sez you,-confidential-like, and
between man and man,-sez you, 'Do you know any-
thing in his behalf?' and I sez to you, sez I-con-
fidential-like, as between man and man,-'What should
a man know of his pardner?'
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Is this all you have to say?
speaker: the Judge

utterance:
That's it, gentlemen, and ladies, as has lived long in
this yer camp, must know, that Tennessee thar is my
pardner. And I was his pardner long afore he ever
see this yer camp. Bein' nowise responsible for his
acts, but bein' as I was his pardner, Thar ain't for me to say anything agin' him. And now, what's the case? Here's Tennessee wants money,
wants it bad, and doesn't like to ask it of his old
pardner. Well, what does Tennessee do? He lays
for a stranger, and he fetches that stranger. And you
lays for him, and you fetches him; and the honors is
easy. And I put it to you, bein' a far-minded man,
and to you, gentlemen, all, as far-minded men, ef this
isn't so.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance:
Prisoner, have you
any questions to ask this man?
speaker: the Judge

utterance:
No! no! I play this yer hand alone. To come down to the
bed-rock, it's just this: Tennessee, thar, has played it
pretty rough and expensive-like on a stranger, and on
this yer camp. And now, what's the fair thing?
Some would say more; some would say less. Here's
seventeen hundred dollars in coarse gold and a watch,
-it's about all my pile,-and call it square!
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Euchred, old man!
speaker: Tennessee

utterance:
I just dropped
in as I was passin' to see how things was gettin' on.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance:
Ef thar is any
present, as
would care to jine in the fun'l, they kin come.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: When a man has been running free all day, what's the natural thing for him to do? Why, to come home. And if he ain't in a condition to go home, what can his best friend do? Why, bring him home! And here's Tennessee has been running free, and we brings him home from his wandering.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: It ain't the first time that I've packed him on my back, as you see'd me now. It ain't the first time that I brought him to this yer cabin when he couldn't help himself; it ain't the first time that I and 'Jinny' have waited for him on yon hill, and picked him up and so fetched him home, when he couldn't speak and didn't know me. And now that it's the last time, why-you see it's sort of rough on his pardner. And now, gentlemen, the fun'l's over; and my thanks, and Tennessee's thanks, to you for your trouble.
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: It is time to go for Tennessee; I must put 'Jinny' in the cart
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: There, now, steady, 'Jinny,'-steady, old girl. How dark it is! Look out for the ruts,-and look out for him, too, old gal. Sometimes, you know, when he's blind drunk, he drops down right in the trail. Keep on straight up to the pine on the top of the hill. Thar-I told you so!-thar he is,-coming this way, too, all by himself, sober, and his face a-shining. Tennessee! Pardner!
speaker: Tennessee's Partner

utterance: Beasts!
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Su'shine all ri'! Wasser maär, eh? Wass up, su'shine?
speaker: Sandy

utterance: Wass up? Wasser maär?
speaker: Sandy

utterance: Get up, you horrid man!
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Wass I go home for?
speaker: Sandy

utterance: Go and take a bath
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Goodness Heavens!-the man will be drowned!
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Abner hasn't been tight since last 'lection.
speaker: Mrs. Stidger

utterance: I think I find the intoxicated portion of this community the least objectionable. I refer, my dear, to the men, of course. I do not know anything that could make the women tolerable.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: If you carried more of that for yourself, you'd do better.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: I heerd tell that you were goin' down to the Bay to-morrow, and I couldn't let you go until I came to thank you for your kindness to my Tommy.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Thank you, miss; thank ye! I thank you, miss, for that! and if I am his mother, there ain't a sweeter, dearer, better boy lives than him. And if I ain't much as says it, thar ain't a sweeter, dearer, angeler teacher lives than he's got.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: It ain't for you to be complimented by the like of me, I know. It ain't for me to be comin' here, in broad day, to do it, either; but I come to ask a favor,-not for me, miss,-not for me, but for the darling boy.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: You see, miss, there's no one the boy has any claim on but me, and I ain't the proper person to bring him up. I thought some, last year, of sending him away to 'Frisco to school, but when they talked of bringing a schoolma'am here, I waited till I saw you, and then I knew it was all right, and I could keep my boy a little longer. And O, miss, he loves you so much; and if you could hear him talk about you, in his pretty way, and if he could ask you what I ask you now, you couldn't refuse him.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: It is natural that he should take to you, miss, for his father, when I first knew him, was a gentleman,—and the boy must forget me, sooner or later,—and so I ain't a goin' to cry about that. For I come to ask you to take my Tommy,-God bless him for the bestest, sweetest boy that lives,-to-to-take him with you.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Put him in some good school, where you can go and see him, and help him to-to-to forget his mother. Do with him what you like. The worst you can do will be kindness to what he will learn with me. Only take him out of this wicked life, this cruel place, this home of shame and sorrow. You will; I know you will, won't you? You will,-you must not, you cannot say no! You will make him as pure, as gentle as yourself; and when he has grown up, you will tell him his father's name,-the name that hasn't passed my lips for years,--the name of Alexander Morton, whom they call here Sandy! Miss Mary!-do not take your hand away! Miss Mary, speak to me! You will take my boy? Do not put your face from me. I know it ought not to look on such as me. Miss Mary!-my God, be merciful!-she is leaving me!
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: I know it takes time to consider. I will wait here all night; but I cannot go until you speak. Do not deny me now. You will!-I see it in your sweet face, such a face as I have seen in my dreams. I see it in your eyes, Miss Mary!-you will take my boy!
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: I will take the boy. Send him to me to-night.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Does this man-know of your intention?
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: No, nor cares. He has never even seen the child to know it.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Go to him at once,-to-night,—now! Tell him what you have done. Tell him I have taken his child, and tell him—he must never see-see-the child again. Wherever it may be, he must not come; wherever I may take it, he must not follow! There, go now, please,-I'm weary, and—have much yet to do!
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: Good night.
speaker: the dubious mother

utterance: Not that bush, Tommy,-the next.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: All right now?
speaker: Tommy

utterance: All right.
speaker: Miss Mary

utterance: I thought Kate was here;
speaker: Brown

utterance: You didn't come up on the stage, did you?
speaker: Brown

utterance: No, I left it at Scott's Ferry. It isn't due for half an hour yet. But how's luck, Brown?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: D- bad, I'm cleaned out again. Jack, can't you help me with a hundred till to-morrow's clean-up? You see I've got to send money home to the old woman, and-you've won twenty times that amount from me.
speaker: Brown

utterance: The old woman business is about played out, Brown, why don't you say you want to buck agin' faro? You know you ain't married!
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Fact, sir, I've got a wife-a d-- good one, too, if I do say it-in the States. It's three year since I've seen her, and a year since I've writ to her. When things is about straight, and we get down to the lead, I'm going to send for her.
speaker: Brown

utterance: And Kate?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: D—— it, Jack, a man must have a little liberty, you know. But come, what do you say to a little game? Give us a show to double this hundred.
speaker: Brown

utterance: It's Kate.
speaker: Brown

utterance: My old woman, by thunder!
speaker: Brown

utterance: What do you see down the road?
speaker: Colonel Starbottle

utterance: Dust. Only Sister Anne's 'flock of sheep.'
speaker: Kate

utterance: It ain't sheep, it's a horseman. Judge, ain't that Jack Hamlin's gray?
speaker: Colonel Starbottle

utterance: This yer's my home, Jack. Her room's t' other end of the hall. It's more'n six months since we've lived together, or met, except at meals. It's mighty rough papers on the head of the house, ain't it? But I'm glad to see you, Jack, d—glad.
speaker: Brown

utterance: I broight ye up here, for I didn't want to talk in the stable; though, for the matter of that, it's all round town. Don't strike a light. We can talk here in the moonshine. Put up your feet on that winder, and sit here beside me. Thar's whiskey in that jug.
speaker: Brown

utterance: If I didn't love the woman, Jack, I wouldn't mind. But it's loving her, and seeing her, day arter day, goin' on at this rate, and no one to put down the brake; that's what gits me! But I'm glad to see ye, Jack, d―― glad.
speaker: Brown

utterance: How long has this been going on?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Ever since she came here; ever since the day she walked into the Magnolia. I was a fool then; Jack, I'm a fool now; but I didn't know how much I loved her till then. And she hasn't been the same woman since.
speaker: Brown

utterance: But that ain't all, Jack; and it's what I wanted to see you about, and I'm glad you've come. It ain't that she doesn't love me any more; it ain't that she fools with every chap that comes along, for, perhaps, I staked her love and lost it, as I did everything else at the Magnolia; and, perhaps, foolin' is nateral to some women, and thar ain't no great harm done, 'cept to the fools. But, Jack, I think,-I think she loves somebody else. Don't move, Jack; don't move; if your pistol hurts ye, take it off.
speaker: Brown

utterance: It's been more 'n six months now that she's seemed unhappy and lonesome, and kinder nervous and scared like. And sometimes I've ketched her lookin' at me sort of timid and pitying. And she writes to somebody. And for the last week she's been gathering her own things,-trinkets, and furbelows, and iew'lry and. Jack. I think she's goin' off. I could thief-
speaker: Brown

utterance: What shall I do, Jack?
speaker: Brown

utterance: Spot the man, and kill him on sight.
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: But, Jack?
speaker: Brown

utterance: He's took the risk!
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: But will that bring her back?
speaker: Brown

utterance: Don't go yet, Jack; light the candle, and sit by the table. It's a comfort to see ye, if nothin' else.
speaker: Brown

utterance: What's that, Jack?
speaker: Brown

utterance: Nothing.
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Are you there, Jack?
speaker: Brown

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Don't go yet. I dreamed just now, Jack,-dreamed of old times. I thought that Sue and me was being married agin, and that the parson, Jack, was—who do you think?-you!
speaker: Brown

utterance: It's a good sign, ain't it?
speaker: Brown

utterance: I reckon. Say, old man, hadn't you better get up?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Smoke?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Light?
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Old man, in ten minutes I'll be on the road, and gone like that spark. We won't see each other agin; but, before I go, take a fool's advice: sell out all you've got, take your wife with you, and quit the country. It ain't no place for you, nor her. Tell her she must go; make her go, if she won't. Don't whine because you can't be a saint, and she ain't an angel. Be a man, and treat her like a woman. Don't be a d-fool. Good by.
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Saddle my horse in two minutes, or I'll-
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: The missis said you was to have the buggy,
speaker: the hostler

utterance: D-n the buggy!
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: Is anything up, Mr. Hamlin?
speaker: the hostler

utterance: Stand aside!
speaker: Jack Hamlin

utterance: What can she want here?
speaker: The Master

utterance: I come here to-night, because I knew you was alone. I wouldn't come here when them gals was here. I hate 'em and they hates me. That's why. You keep school, don't you? I want to be teached!
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: My name's Mliss,-Mliss Smith! You can bet your life on that. My father's Old Smith,-Old Bummer Smith, that's what's the matter with him. Mliss Smith, -and I'm coming to school!
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Well?
speaker: The Master

utterance: she'd be good, she didn't mean to
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Why had she left the Sabbath school?-why? O yes. What did he (McSnagley) want to tell her she was wicked for? What did he tell her that God hated her for? If God hated her, what did she want to go to Sabbath school for? She didn't want to be "beholden" to anybody who hated her.
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Had she told McSnagley this?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Yes, she had.
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: Her father? What father? Whose father? What had he ever done for her? Why did the girls hate her? Come now! what made the folks say, "Old Bummer Smith's Mliss!" when she passed? Yes; O yes. She wished he was dead,—she was dead,-everybody was dead;
speaker: Melissa Smith

utterance: good night.
speaker: The Master

utterance: Are you busy? Can you come with me?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Come, then, quick!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: To see my father.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: What do you want?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: I want some crab-apples.
speaker: The Master

utterance: Sha' n't have 'em! go away. Why don't you get 'em of Clytemnerestera? O you wicked thing!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: I am hungry, Lissy. I have eaten nothing since dinner yesterday. I am famished!
speaker: The Master

utterance: Dig under the tree near the roots, and you'll find lots; but mind you don't tell
speaker: Mliss

utterance: If I come down and give you some, you'll promise you won't touch me?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Hope you'll die if you do!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Do you feel better?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Lissy, do you remember the first evening you came to see me?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Come
speaker: Mliss

utterance: What would you say if the master now came to you and said that he was lonely without his little scholar, and that he wanted her to come and teach him to be better?
speaker: The Master

utterance: We are waiting, Lissy.
speaker: The Master

utterance: Meelissy! ye were speaking of the revolutions of this yere yearth and the move-ments of the sun, and I think ye said it had been a doing of it since the creashun, eh?
speaker: Rev. Joshua McSnagley

utterance: Stick to it, Mliss!
speaker: unnamed

utterance: Joshua commanded the sun to stand still, and it obeyed him!
speaker: Clytemnestra Morpher

utterance: It's a d-n lie. I don't believe it!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Now take me home!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Why?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Please, sir?
speaker: Aristides

utterance: Well, my little man, what is it? quick!
speaker: The Master

utterance: Please, sir, me and 'Kerg' thinks that Mliss is going to run away agin.
speaker: Aristides

utterance: What's that, sir?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Why, sir, she don't stay home any more, and 'Kerg' and me see her talking with one of those actor fellers, and she's with him now; and please, sir, yesterday she told 'Kerg' and me she could make a speech as well as Miss Cellerstina Montmoressy, and she spouted right off by heart
speaker: Aristides

utterance: What actor?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Him as wears the shiny hat. And hair. And gold pin. And gold chain
speaker: Aristides

utterance: Where were they talking?
speaker: The Master

utterance: At the Arcade
speaker: Aristides

utterance: Run down home. If Mliss is there, come to the Arcade and tell me. If she isn't there, stay home; run!
speaker: The Master

utterance: S'pose she has?
speaker: the dramatic company agent

utterance: I understand that Melissa Smith, an orphan, and one of my scholars, has talked with you about adopting your profession. Is that so?
speaker: The Master

utterance: If you are a gentleman, I have only to tell you that I am her guardian, and responsible for her career. You know as well as I do the kind of life you offer her. As you may learn of any one here, I have already brought her out of an existence worse than death,- out of the streets and the contamination of vice. I am trying to do so again. Let us talk like men. She has neither father, mother, sister, or brother. Are you seeking to give her an equivalent for these?
speaker: The Master

utterance: I know that she is a strange, wilful girl, but she is better than she was. I believe that I have some influence over her still. I beg and hope, therefore, that you will take no further steps in this matter, but as a man, as a gentleman, leave her to me. I am willing-
speaker: The Master

utterance: Want her yourself, do you? That cock won't fight here, young man!
speaker: the dramatic company agent

utterance: It's all right, my boy. She's home!
speaker: Mr. Morpher

utterance: Did you kill him?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: No!
speaker: The Master

utterance: That's what I gave you the knife for!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Gave me the knife?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Yes, gave you the knife. I was there under the bar. Saw you hit him. Saw you both fall. He dropped his old knife. I gave it to you. Why didn't you stick him?
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Yes. If you'd asked me, I'd told you I was off with the play-actors. Why was I off? Because I knew you was going away. I knew it. I heard you tell the Doctor so. I wasn't a goin' to stay here alone with those Morphers. I'd rather die first.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: That's the poison plant you said would kill me. I'll go with the play-actors, or I'll eat this and die here. I don't care which. I won't stay here, where they hate and despise me! Neither would you let me, if you didn't hate and despise me too!
speaker: Mliss

utterance: If you lock me up in jail, to keep me from the play-actors, I'll poison myself. Father killed himself,-why shouldn't I? You said a mouthful of that root would kill me, and I always carry it here
speaker: Mliss

utterance: Lissy, will you go with me?
speaker: The Master

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: But now-to-night?
speaker: The Master

utterance: To-night.
speaker: Mliss

utterance: I sez to Mariar, 'Mariar,' sez I, 'Praise to the face is open disgrace.'
speaker: an unnamed character

utterance: I thought you changed horses on the road?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: So we did. Two hours ago.
speaker: Profane Bill

utterance: That's odd. I didn't notice it.
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Must have been asleep, sir. Hope you had a pleasant nap. Bully place for a nice quiet snooze,- empty stage, sir!
speaker: Profane Bill

utterance: I'm going home!
speaker: Fagg

utterance: Going home?
speaker: The narrator

utterance:
Yes, that is, I think I'll take a trip to the At-
lantic States. I came to see you, as you know I have
some little property, and I have executed a power of
attorney for you to manage my affairs. I have some
papers I'd like to leave with you. Will you take
charge of them?
speaker: Fagg

utterance: Yes
speaker: The narrator

utterance: But what of Nellie?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: I shall not marry Nellie,—that is,
speaker: Fagg

utterance: I think that I had better not.
speaker: Fagg

utterance:
David Fagg, you're
of no account!
speaker: The narrator

utterance:
Yes, that's it!-I'm of no account! But I always
knew it. You see I thought Rattler loved that girl as
well as I did, and I knew she liked him better than
she did me, and would be happier I dare say with
him. But then I knew that old Robins would have
preferred me to him, as I was better off,-and the girl
would do as he said,-and, you see, I thought I was
kinder in the way,—and so I left. But,
speaker: Fagg

utterance:
for fear the old man
might object to Rattler, I've lent him enough to set
him up in business for himself in Dogtown. A push-
ing, active, brilliant fellow, you know, like Rattler can
get along, and will soon be in his old position again,
—and you needn't be hard on him, you know, if he
doesn't. Good by.
speaker: Fagg

utterance: You see, stranger
speaker: an intelligent informant

utterance:
gold is sure to come out'er
that theer claim
speaker: an intelligent informant

utterance:
but the old pro-pri-e-tor warn't of much account. He was green,
and let the boys about here jump him,
speaker: an intelligent informant

utterance: His name war Fagg.
speaker: an intelligent informant

utterance: so, so.
speaker: Fagg

Ah, yes! Land Warrants,—and then this was Mr.
Tryan?

utterance:
Now, then, which on ye'll see the stranger up the
creek to Altascar's, to-morrow?
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Kin you go, Kerg?
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Who's to look up stock in Strarberry per-ar-ie?

utterance: Well, Tom, wot's to hinder you from goin'?
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance:
Mam 's goin' to Brown's store at sun-up, and I
s'pose I've got to pack her and the baby agin.
speaker: Tom

utterance: Plenty get well, skeena mowitch,
speaker: old squaw

utterance: wagee man come plenty soon,
speaker: old squaw

utterance: Wise?
speaker: Wise

utterance: I told ye to get Brown to give you a pair the last time you war down the river.
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Said he wouldn't without'en order. Said it was like pulling gum-teeth to get the money from you even then.
speaker: Joe

utterance: Well, Joe, ef your boots are new, and you aren't pestered with wimmin and children, p'r'aps you'll go.
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Got no saddle.
speaker: Tom

utterance: Wot's gone of your saddle?
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Kerg, there.
speaker: Tom

utterance: You lie!
speaker: Kerg

utterance: Theer's George comin'! why don't ye ask him? He'll go and introduce you to Don Fernandy's darter, too, ef you ain't pertickler.
speaker: Wise

utterance: You'd better sleep there to-night, you'll be more comfortable, and I'll call you early.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Ours!
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: About how many, George?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Don't know.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: How many?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Well, p'r'aps three thousand head.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: What are they worth?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: About thirty dollars a head.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: I've tried to get the old man to sell and build, but you know he says it ain't no use to settle down, just yet. We must keep movin'. In fact, he built the shanty for that purpose, lest titles should fall through, and we'd have to get up and move stakes further down.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Toro!
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: That's not our brand.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Never horsemen,—sometimes footmen. Not through rage, you know, but curiosity. They think a man and his horse are one, and if they meet a chap afoot, they run him down and trample him under hoof, in the pursuit of knowledge. But, here's the lower bench of the foothills, and here's Altascar's corral, and that white building you see yonder is the casa.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Que bueno?-Your courts are always inst
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: The deputies will be here to-morrow to run the lines from this initial point, and there will be no further trouble, I believe, gentlemen.
speaker: The narrator

utterance: And I, Fernando Jesus Maria Altascar, put you in possession of my land in the fashion of my country.
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: I don't know your courts, your judges, or your corregidores. Take the llano!-and take this with it. May the drought seize your cattle till their tongues hang down as long as those of your lying lawyers! May it be the curse and torment of your old age, as you and yours have made it of mine!
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: Let him curse on. He'll find 'em coming home. to him sooner than the cattle he has lost through his sloth and pride. The Lord is on the side of the just, as well as agin all slanderers and revilers.
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Stealer of the Sacrament! Open not!-open not, I say, your lying, Judas lips to me! Ah! half-breed, with the soul of a cayote!-Car-r-r-ramba!
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: Will you go back with us to-night?
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Well then, good by.
speaker: George Tryan

utterance: Good by, George.
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Light ahead.
speaker: bow oar

utterance: Stern, all; a steamer!
speaker: unclear

utterance: Hold hard there! Steamer be d-d! It's a house, and a big one too.
speaker: coxswain

utterance: There's some one in it, by Heavens! Give way, boys, lay her alongside. Handsomely, now! The door's fastened; try the window; no! here's another!
speaker: unclear

utterance: Joseph Tryan!
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Look up, old man, look up! Your wife and children, where are they? The boys,-George! Are they here? are they safe?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Joseph Tryan, don't you know me? the surveyor who surveyed your ranch,—the Espíritu Santo? Look up, old man!
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Hush!
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Listen!
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: I'm a moving off!
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Moving off?
speaker: The narrator

utterance: Hush! Don't speak so loud. Moving off. Ah! wot's that? Don't you hear?-there! listen!
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: They have been here all night. I heard 'em first in the creek, when they came to tell the old man to move farther off. They came nearer and nearer. They whispered under the door, and I saw their eyes on the step,- their cruel, hard eyes. Ah, why don't they quit?
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: Why don't they quit, then? They have the stock, -all gone-gone, gone for the hides and hoofs.
speaker: Mr. Tryan

utterance: There are other boats below us. The shanty cannot have drifted far, and perhaps the family are safe by this time.
speaker: coxswain

utterance: "Is it George Tryan?"
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "Don't know; but he's a sweet one, whoever he is. You'll find him for'ard."
speaker: the engineer

utterance: "These are high old times, ain't they? I say, what do you reckon's become o' them thar bound'ry moni- ments you stuck? Ah!"
speaker: Wise

utterance: "So you've picked up the ole man in the shanty, clean crazy? He must have been soft to have stuck there instead o' leavin' with the old woman. Didn't know me from Adam; took me for George!"
speaker: Wise

utterance: "Don't know whar he is! If he'd tended stock instead of running about the prairie, packin' off wim- 177 lost every hoof and hide, I'll bet a cookey! Say you, when are you goin' to give us some grub? I'm hungry 'nough to skin and eat a hoss. Reckon I'll turn butcher when things is dried up, and save hides, horns, and taller."
speaker: Wise

utterance: "Have you any idea what you'll do, Wise?"
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "Thar ain't much to do now. I'll have to lay over a spell, I reckon, till things comes straight. The land ain't worth much now, and won't be, I dessay, for some time. Wonder whar the ole man 'll drive stakes next."
speaker: Wise

utterance: "I meant as to your father and George, Wise."
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "O, the ole man and I'll go on to 'Miles's,' whar Tom packed the old woman and babies last week. George'll turn up somewhar atween this and Altascar's, ef he ain't thar now."
speaker: Wise

utterance: "Well, I reckon he ain't lost much in stock. I shouldn't wonder if George helped him drive 'em up the foot-hills. And his 'casa' 's built too high. O, thar ain't any water thar, you bet. Ah, those greasers ain't the darned fools people thinks 'em. I'll bet thar ain't one swamped out in all 'er Californy."
speaker: Wise

utterance: "I shall keep on a little farther, and try to find George."
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "I don't think you'll save much. What's the per- centage, workin' on shares, eh!"
speaker: Wise

utterance: "Poco a poco Señor,-not now. You are tired, you have hunger, you have cold. Necessary it is you should have peace."
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "You have eat?"
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "Bueno, eat when you can,-food and appetite are not always."
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "It was made by me, Señor."
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "I kept it as a clew to him, Don Altascar. If I could find him-"
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "He is here."
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "Here! and'--but I could not say, 'well!'"
speaker: The narrator

utterance: "He was honest and brave,"
speaker: Señor Altascar

utterance: "I ask your pardon, Sir Priest, for disturbing your meditations. Pleasant they must have been, and right fanciful, I imagine, when occa- sioned by so fair a prospect."
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "Worldly, perhaps, Sir Devil,-for such I take you to be, worldly, perhaps; for it hath pleased Heaven to retain even in our rege- nerated state much that pertaineth to the flesh, yet still, I trust, not without some speculation for the welfare of the Holy Church. In dwelling upon yon fair ex- panse, mine eyes have been graciously opened with prophetic inspiration, and the promise of the heathen as an inheritance hath marvellously recurred to me. For there can be none lack such diligence in the True Faith, but may see that even the conversion of these pitiful salvages hath a meaning. As the blessed St. Ignatius discreetly observes, the heathen is given to the warriors of Christ, even as the pearls of rare discovery which gladden the hearts of shipmen.' Nay, I might say-"
speaker: Father José Antonio Haro

utterance: "It grieves me, Sir Priest, to interrupt the current of your eloquence as discourteously as I have already broken your meditations: but the day already waneth to night. I have a matter of serious import to make with you, could I entreat your cautious consideration a few moments."
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Farewell, ye gallant cavaliers and Christian sol- de Ojeda! and thou, most venerable Las Casas! Fare- well, and may Heaven prosper still the seed ye left behind!
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Pardon this weakness, Sir Priest, but these worthy gentlemen were ancient friends of mine, and have done me many a delicate service,—much more, perchance, than these poor sables may signify.
speaker: a stranger

utterance: But the seed they have planted shall thrive and prosper on this fruitful soil.
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Look to the East!
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Who are these swaggering Ishmaelites?
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: What do they here, with neither cross nor holy symbol?
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Have you the courage to see, Sir Priest?
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Step under the shadow of my plume.
speaker: a stranger

utterance: This, then, Sir Devil, is your work! This is your deceitful lure for the weak souls of sinful nations! So would you replace the Christian grace of holy Spain!
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: This is what must be. But listen, Sir Priest. It lies with you to avert the issue for a time. Leave me here in peace. Go back to Castile, and take with you your bells, your images, and your missions. Continue here, and you only precipitate results. Stay! promise me you will do this, and you shall not lack that which will render your old age an ornament and a blessing.
speaker: the Devil

utterance: Avaunt thee, Sathanas! Diabolus, I defy thee! What! wouldst thou bribe me,-me, a brother of the Sacred Society of the Holy Jesus, Licentiate of Cor- dova and Inquisitor of Guadalaxara? Thinkest thou to buy me with thy sordid treasure? Avaunt!
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: A miracle! Blessed Saint José, he lives!
speaker: Ignacio

utterance: On the mountain, your Reverence, but a few varas from where he attacked you.
speaker: Ignacio

utterance: How?—you saw him then?
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Saw him, your Reverence! Mother of God, I should think I did! And your Reverence shall see him too, if he ever comes again within range of Igna- cio's arquebuse.
speaker: Ignacio

utterance: What mean you, Ignacio?
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Why, the bear, your Reverence, the bear, Holy Father, who attacked your worshipful person while you were meditating on the top of yonder mountain.
speaker: Ignacio

utterance: Ah!
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Chut, child! I would be at peace.
speaker: Father José Maria

utterance: Abimelech took her from Abraham'-ah, little one, excellent!-'Jacob sent to see his brother' -body of Christ! that up-stroke of thine, Paquita, is marvellous; the Governor shall see it!
speaker: Hermenegildo Salvatierra

utterance: For yourself, Señor Captain, accept my hospitality. The fort is yours as long as you shall grace it with your dis- tinguished presence.
speaker: Hermenegildo Salvatierra

utterance: Ah, littlest of all, sweet one, what doest thou here? Art thou not afraid of him whom every one shuns and fears?
speaker: Hermenegildo Salvatierra

utterance: No, not in the dark. I hear your voice,—the old voice; I feel your touch, the old touch; but I see not your eye, Señor Comandante. That only I fear, and that, O Señor, O my father, that I know is not thine own!
speaker: Paquita

utterance: "The tide will turn soon, or something will happen."
speaker: a broker

utterance: "If so be, camarados and brothers all, ye are ready to receive the report of our excellent and well-beloved brother, Master Slit-the-Weazand, touching his search for this treasure, why, marry, to't and begin."
speaker: Malmsey Butt

utterance: "Go to! thou wast always a tall fellow!"
speaker: None

utterance: "Let me go!"
speaker: a broker

utterance: "Let me go! I tell you, gentlemen, that document is not worth the parchment it is written on. The laws of the State, the customs of the country, the mining ordinances, are all against it. Don't, by all that's sacred, throw away such a capital investment through ignorance and informality. Let me go! I assure you, gentlemen, professionally, that you have a big thing,-a remarkably big thing, and even if I ain't in it, I'm not going to see it fall through. Don't, for God's sake, gentlemen, I implore you, put your names to such a ridiculous paper. There isn't a notary—"
speaker: a broker

utterance: "halloo"
speaker: None

utterance: "Her Majestie is very sicke, Lord Essex hath ye measles, Our Admiral hath licked ye French- Poppe! saith ye weasel!"
speaker: the party

utterance: "I am ycleped J. Keyser-I was born at Spring, hys Garden, My father toe make me ane clerke erst did essaye, But a fico for ye offis-I spurn ye losels offeire; For I fain would be ane butcher by'r ladykin alwaye."
speaker: Malmsey Butt

utterance: "Gad's life! hast no more bones in thy fat carcass than a jelly-fish? Lend a hand, here! Yo, heave ho!"
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "Now, then, who and what art thou?"
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "To think that I should stumble upon the very man I was seeking! Body of Bacchus! but this is lucky! Follow me quickly, for there is no time to lose."
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "The bells! did you not hear them?"
speaker: Father Vicentio

utterance: "Tush! tush! thy fall hath set triple bob-majors ringing in thine ears. Come on!"
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "Look! dost thou not see the stately squares and brilliantly lighted avenues of a mighty metropolis. Dost thou not see, as it were, another firmament below?"
speaker: Father Vicentio

utterance: "Avast heaving, reverend man, and quit this folly. Behold rather the stars knocked out of thy hollow noddle by the fall thou hast had. Prithee, get over thy visions and rhapsodies, for the time is wearing apace."
speaker: a stranger

utterance: "Thou seest before thee, reverend father, a helpless mortal, struggling not only with the last agonies of the flesh, but beaten down and tossed with sore anguish of the spirit. It matters little when or how I became what thou now seest me. Enough that my life has been ungodly and sinful, and that my only hope of absolution lies in my imparting to thee a secret which is of vast importance to the holy Church, and affects greatly her power, wealth, and dominion on these shores. But the terms of this secret and the conditions of my absolution are peculiar. I have but five minutes to live. In that time I must receive the extreme unction of the Church."
speaker: a dying man

utterance: "And thy secret?"
speaker: Father Vicentio

utterance: "Shall be told afterwards. Come, my time is short. Shrive me quickly."
speaker: a dying man

utterance: "Couldst thou not tell this secret first?"
speaker: Father Vicentio

utterance: "Impossible!"
speaker: a dying man

utterance: "Shrive me! shrive me!"
speaker: a dying man

utterance: "Let me know at least what this secret concerns?"
speaker: Father Vicentio

utterance: "Shrive me first"
speaker: a dying man

utterance: "Dear me! that's very singular; one of my most popular flies, too! Why, they'd have risen by shoals in Broadway or Beacon Street for that. Well, here goes another."
speaker: the Devil

utterance: "I've heard of these San-Franciscans before, wait till I get hold of one,-that's all!"
speaker: the Devil

utterance: "Come,"
speaker: the Devil

utterance: "Don't flatter yourself that you're a prize either. I was certain to have had you. It was only a question of time."
speaker: the Devil

utterance: "It is not that, my lord, which troubles me, but that I should have been fooled by such a paltry bait. What will they say of me down there? To have let 'bigger things' go by, and to be taken in by this cheap trick, is what,-pardon me, my lord,-is what gets me!"
speaker: a portly two-hundred-pound broker

utterance: "Yes, I never caught anybody yet who didn't say that; but tell me, ain't you getting somewhat fastidious down there? Here is one of my most popular flies, the greenback,"
speaker: the Devil

utterance: "I REMEMBER him a little boy,"
speaker: the Duchess

utterance:
"His mother was a dear friend of mine; you know she
was one of my bridesmaids."
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: "And you have never seen him since, mamma?"
speaker: the oldest married daughter

utterance:
"Never; he was an orphan shortly after. I have
often reproached myself, but it is so difficult to see
boys."
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: "Mamma, I've just dropped a pearl,"
speaker: the Lady Coriander

utterance: "From your lips, sweet friend,"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"No, from my work. It was a very valuable pearl,
mamma; papa gave Isaacs and Sons £50,000 for the
two."
speaker: the Lady Coriander

utterance: "Ah, indeed; let us go to luncheon."
speaker: the Duchess

utterance:
"But your Grace, consider
the value-"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "Dear friend, I am waiting for your arm."
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: "I'm going to the hennery,"
speaker: the Duchess

utterance: "Let me go with you, I dearly love fowls-broiled,"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"The Duke gave Lady Montairy some large Cochins
the other day,"
speaker: the Duchess

utterance:
"Lady Montairy,
Quite contrairy,
How do your Cochins grow?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"If you please, ma'am, when I come into my

lings for the poor, and marry Lady Coriander."

utterance:
"You amaze me, dear friend, and yet both your

utterance: "I should say it was a matter of latitude,"
speaker: an Oxford Professor

utterance:
"And how do we all find ourselves
this evening, my dears?"
speaker: His Eminence, the Cardinal

utterance:
"To-morrow, I will partake of
the communion, and endow the Church with my vast
estates. For the present I'll let the improved cot-
tages go."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "Your Lordship is struck by that face,"
speaker: a social parasite

utterance: "I am; who is she?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Her name is Mary Ann. She is married to an
American, and has lately invented a new religion."
speaker: a social parasite

utterance: "Ah!"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "Yes; shall I introduce you?"
speaker: a social parasite

utterance:
"No, I thank
you, not now."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Ah, I believe I have
some land there. If I mistake not, my agent, Mr.
Putney Giles, lately purchased the State of Illinois-
I think you call it."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Exactly. As a former resident of the city of
Chicago, let me introduce myself as your tenant."
speaker: Major-General Camperdown

utterance: "We have met before. Pray tell me, what is this new religion of yours?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"It is Woman Suffrage, Free Love, Mutual Affinity,
and Communism. Embrace it and me."
speaker: Mary Ann

utterance:
"My husband will be too happy to talk with you
further on this subject. Come with us to
Oneida. Brook Farm is a thing of the past."
speaker: Mary Ann

utterance: "What does he say?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "My Mary Ann."
speaker: a driver

utterance:
"I will send Mary
Ann a handsome present,' "
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Each of these pearls, my Lord, is worth fifty
thousand guineas,"
speaker: Mr. Amethyst

utterance:
"Indeed, I should prefer
to see some expensive ones."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Some number sixes, I suppose. These are about the size
of the Duchess of Billingsgate's, but they are in finer
condition. The fact is, her Grace permits her two
children, the Marquis of Smithfield and the Duke of
St. Giles,-two sweet pretty boys, my Lord,-to use
them as marbles in their games. Pearls require some
attention, and I go down there regularly twice a week
to clean them. Perhaps your Lordship would like
some ropes of pearls?"
speaker: Mr. Amethyst

utterance: "About half a cable's length, and send them to my lodgings."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"I am afraid I
have not the exact number-that is-excuse me one
moment. I will run over to the Tower and borrow a
few from the crown jewels."
speaker: Mr. Amethyst

utterance:
"You can search me, if you like; but I assure you, upon the honor
of a gentleman, that I have taken nothing."
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "Enough, my Lord; we never search the aristocracy."
speaker: Mr. Amethyst

utterance: "How is Mary Ann?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "I regret to state that she is dying,"

utterance: "Dying!"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"Alas, too true! The en-
gagements of a long lecturing season, exposure in

fect nourishment afforded by the refreshments along
the road, have told on her delicate frame. But she
want to
ou before she dies Howe in
speaker: Major-General Camperdown

utterance:
"Open-air speaking twice a week, and saleratus
bread in the rural districts, have brought me to this,"
speaker: Mary Ann

utterance:
"Promise me one thing. Don't-whatever you do
—become a Catholic."
speaker: Mary Ann

utterance: "Why?"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance:
"The Church does not recognize divorce. And
now embrace me. I would prefer at this supreme
moment to introduce myself to the next world through
the medium of the best society in this. Good by.
When I am dead, be good enough to inform my hus-
band of the fact."
speaker: Mary Ann

utterance:
"This is an Aryan landscape, and
that is a Mary Ann statue."
speaker: the Host

utterance: "If you please, I should like to become a Pagan,"
speaker: Lothaw

utterance: "The young ladies are in the garden. Don't you want to go and pick a rose?"
speaker: the Duchess

utterance:
"Bless you, my children. You have simply ful-
filled and accepted your inevitable destiny.
It was
morally impossible for you to marry out of this family.
For the present, the Church of England is safe."
speaker: the Duchess

utterance:
"Genevra, the logs which compose yonder fire
seem to have been incautiously chosen. The sibilation
produced by the sap, which exudes copiously there-
from, is not conducive to composition."
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance:
"True, father, but I thought it would be preferable
to the constant crepitation which is apt to attend the
combustion of more seasoned ligneous fragments."
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"Why does the Pale Face still follow the track of the
Red Man? Why does he pursue him, even as O-kee-
chow, the wild-cat, chases Ka-ka, the skunk? Why
are the feet of Sorrel-top, the white chief, among the
acorns of Muck-a-Muck, the mountain forest? Why,
why do you seek to drive him from
the wigwams of his fathers? His brothers are already
gone to the happy hunting-grounds. Will the Pale
Face seek him there?"
speaker: Muck-a-Muck

utterance:
"Muck-a-Muck has spoken. Let him now listen. Are the acorns of the mountain
sweeter than the esculent and nutritious bean of the
Pale Face miner? Does my brother prize the edible
qualities of the snail above that of the crisp and olea-
ginous bacon? Delicious are the grasshoppers that
sport on the hillside,-are they better than the dried
apples of the Pale Faces? Pleasant is the gurgle of
the torrent, Kish-Kish, but is it better than the cluck-
cluck of old Bourbon from the old stone bottle?"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"Ugh! good. The
White Rabbit is wise. Her words fall as the snow on
Tootoonolo, and the rocky heart of Muck-a-Muck is
hidden. What says my brother the Gray Gopher of
Dutch Flat?"
speaker: Muck-a-Muck

utterance:
"She has spoken, Muck-a-Muck. It is well. Our
treaty is concluded. No, thank you,-you need not
dance the Dance of Snow Shoes, or the Moccasin
Dance, the Dance of Green Corn, or the Treaty
Dance. I would be alone. A strange sadness over-
powers me."
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance:
"I go. Tell your great chief
in Washington, the Sachem Andy, that the Red Man
is retiring before the footsteps of the adventurous
Pioneer. Inform him, if you please, that westward
the star of empire takes its way, that the chiefs of the
P-Ute nation are for Reconstruction to a man, and
that Klamath will poll a heavy Republican vote in the
fall."
speaker: Muck-a-Muck

utterance:
"He
may never return again, at least, with unbroken bones.
Should he meet with an accident! I mind me now a
fearful legend, familiar to my childhood. Can it be
that the drivers on this line are privately instructed to
despach all passengers maimed by accident, to prevent
tedious litigation? No, no. But why this weight upon
my heart?"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"O Arrah, ma dheelish, the distant dudheen
Lies soft in the moonlight, ma bouchal vourneen:
The springing gossoons on the heather are still,
And the caubeens and colleens are heard on the hills."
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"How
beautiful is Nature!"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"Eternally dog-gone my skin ef this ain't the put-
tiest chance yet."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "My preserver!"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"The soft shining of the moon and the peaceful
ripple of the waves seem to say to us various things
of an instructive and moral tendency."
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"You may bet yer pile on that, Miss. It's all the preachin' and psalm-
singin' I've heern since I was a boy."
speaker: Natty Bumpo

utterance:
"Noble being! Reared in this wild seclu-
sion, yet he has become penetrated with visible con-
sciousness of a Great First Cause. Methinks 'twere pleasant to
glide ever thus down the stream of life, hand in hand
with the one being whom the soul claims as its affinity.
But what am I saying?"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance: "Ef you mean you're on the marry, I ain't in no wise partikler!"
speaker: Natty Bumpo

utterance: "My husband,"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance:
"Dern their pesky
skins, ef they dare to touch my Jenny,"
speaker: Natty Bumpo

utterance: "Ye'r not scalped, then!"
speaker: Natty Bumpo

utterance:
"No. I have no hesitation in saying that I am
not; but why this abruptness?"
speaker: Genevra Octavia Tompkins

utterance: "Why, that's her waterfall!"
speaker: Judge Tompkins

utterance:
"How young
he is, a mere child; and yet how noble-looking,"
